htmlEmbed:
Even OpenAI's CEO Says Be Careful What You Share With ChatGPT@CNET7/27/2025

The AI model is not your therapist and the company behind it can't necessarily keep it secret. Sam Altman thinks that's 'very screwed up.'

.nuxt-progress {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0px;
  left: 0px;
  right: 0px;
  height: 2px;
  width: 0%;
  opacity: 1;
  transition: width 0.1s, opacity 0.4s;
  background-color: #fff;
  z-index: 999999;
}
.nuxt-progress.nuxt-progress-notransition {
  transition: none;
}
.nuxt-progress-failed {
  background-color: red;
}

      Even OpenAI's CEO Says Be Careful What You Share With ChatGPT
    </h1> <!----> <!----></div> <p class="u-speakableText-dek c-contentHeader_description g-outer-spacing-top-small">
    The AI model is not your therapist and the company behind it can't necessarily keep it secret. Sam Altman thinks that's 'very screwed up.'
  </p> <div class="c-contentHeader_meta g-text-xxsmall g-inner-spacing-top-medium g-inner-spacing-bottom-medium g-outer-spacing-bottom-large u-flexbox u-flexbox-alignCenter g-border-thin-light-top g-border-thin-light-bottom"><div class="c-globalAuthor u-flexbox c-contentHeader_author"><div data-cy="globalAuthorImage" class="c-globalAuthorImage u-flexbox u-flexbox-alignCenter c-globalAuthorImage-0"><div class="c-cmsImage c-globalAuthorImage_frame g-container-round"><picture class="c-cmsImage_image c-cmsImage-loaded"> <img src="https://www.cnet.com/a/img/resize/98841d2f30db19ca0642b7ae9d0d51b37561f48a/hub/2023/01/10/931ff7fd-78aa-4bd4-b424-379816356ccf/jonreed.jpg?auto=webp&fit=crop&height=96&width=96" alt="Headshot of Jon Reed" height="96" width="96"></picture></div> <div section="authorCard" id="author-card-0" class="col-5 c-globalAuthorCard c-authorCard"><div class="c-globalAuthorCard_head"><div section="author_headshot" class="c-globalAuthorCard_picture"><div class="c-cmsImage"><picture class="c-cmsImage_image c-cmsImage-loaded"> <img src="https://www.cnet.com/a/img/resize/c3e5116b52a8815e2faa84d44980714cd64df4d2/hub/2023/01/10/931ff7fd-78aa-4bd4-b424-379816356ccf/jonreed.jpg?auto=webp&fit=crop&height=84&width=84" alt="Headshot of Jon Reed" height="84" width="84"></picture></div></div> <div class="c-globalAuthorCard_info"><!----> <span class="c-globalAuthorCard_name">Jon Reed</span> <span>Senior Editor</span></div></div> <div class="c-globalAuthorCard_bio">Jon covers artificial intelligence. He previously led CNET's home energy and utilities category, with a focus on energy-saving advice, thermostats, and heating and cooling. Jon has more than a decade of experience writing and reporting, including as a statehouse reporter in Columbus, Ohio, a crime reporter in Birmingham, Alabama, and as a mortgage and housing market editor for Time's former personal finance brand, NextAdvisor.  When he's not asking people questions, he can usually be found half asleep trying to read a long history book while surrounded by multiple cats. You can reach him at joreed@cnet.com</div> <div class="c-globalAuthorCard_details"><span>Expertise</span> <span class="c-globalAuthorCard_description">Artificial intelligence, home energy, heating and cooling, home technology.</span> <!----> <!----></div> <div class="c-globalAuthorCard_linkWrapper"><a href="/profiles/joreed/" rel="author" class="c-globalAuthorCard_link u-flexbox-alignSelfCenter">See full bio</a></div> <!----></div></div> <div class="c-globalAuthor_meta u-flexbox-column u-flexbox-justifyAround"><div class="u-flexbox g-text-bold g-outer-spacing-right-small g-outer-spacing-bottom-xsmall g-text-xsmall"><div class="u-flexbox"><!----> <span class="c-globalAuthor_link c-globalAuthor_link-0"><!----> <span data-cy="authorName" class="c-globalAuthor_name">Jon Reed</span> <!----> <!----></span> <!----> <!----> <!---->
          
        </div></div> <span class="c-globalAuthor_date g-text-xxxsmall g-color-text-meta"><!----> <time data-cy="articleDatePublished">July 25, 2025  12:56 p.m. PT</time></span></div></div> <div class="u-flexbox u-flexbox-alignCenter"><span class="c-contentHeader_readTime g-text-xxxsmall">3 min read</span> <div class="c-socialShareButton c-contentHeader_shareButton"><div><button aria-label="Share on Social Media" class="c-socialShareButton_container"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="c-globalSvgIcon c-socialShareButton_icon"><!----> <use xlink:href="#share"/></svg></button> <!----></div></div></div> <!----></div></div> <!----></div> <div class="c-pageArticleHero sm:u-col-2 md:u-col-6 lg:u-col-8"><div><div class="c-ShortcodeContent c-ShortcodeContent-theme:default"><figure class="c-shortcodeImage u-clearfix c-shortcodeImage-hasCaption c-shortcodeImage-hero"><div class="c-shortcodeImage_imageContainer"><!----> <div class="c-cmsImage c-shortcodeImage_image"><picture class="c-cmsImage_image c-cmsImage-loaded"><source media="(max-width: 767px)" srcset="https://www.cnet.com/a/img/resize/5faf7ce8d00b0d75a572003b6151c23332dbc461/hub/2025/07/25/d61443ea-77fc-4b49-abde-beafe10319e7/gettyimages-2218523666.jpg?auto=webp&fit=crop&height=236&width=420" g-inner-spacing-right-small g-text-xxsmall"><p>OpenAI CEO Sam Altman testifies before a US Senate committee in May 2025.</p></span> <span class="c-shortcodeImage_credit g-inner-spacing-right-small g-outer-spacing-top-xsmall g-color-text-meta g-text-xxxsmall">Demetrius Freeman/The Washington Post via Getty Images</span></figcaption></figure></div></div> <!----></div> <!----> <div id="article-dd241017-0c93-4a39-8cf2-00225242f733" class="c-pageArticle_body sm:u-col-2 md:u-col-6 lg:u-col-6 lg:u-col-start-2"><!----> <div class="c-pageArticle_content"><div class="u-grid-columns"><article class="c-ShortcodeContent c-ShortcodeContent-theme:default sm:u-col-2 md:u-col-6 lg:u-col-12"><p class="u-speakableText-p1">Maybe don't spill your deepest, darkest secrets with an <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/best-ai-chatbots/" target="_self">AI chatbot</a>. You don't have to take my word for it. Take it from the guy behind the most popular generative AI model on the market.</p><!----><p class="u-speakableText-p2">Sam Altman, the CEO of <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/chatgpt-plus-review/" target="_self">ChatGPT</a> maker OpenAI, raised the issue this week in an <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aYn8VKW6vXA" target="_self">interview</a> with host Theo Von on the This Past Weekend podcast. He suggested that your conversations with AI should have similar protections as those you have with your doctor or lawyer. At one point, Von said one reason he was hesitant to use some AI tools is because he "didn't know who's going to have" his personal information.</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><figure class="c-shortcodeImage u-clearfix c-shortcodeImage-small c-shortcodeImage-pullRight"><a rel href="https://www.cnet.com/ai-atlas/" target="_blank" class="c-shortcodeImage_imageContainer"><!----> <div class="c-cmsImage c-shortcodeImage_image"><picture class="c-cmsImage_image"><source media="(max-width: 767px)" srcset="https://www.cnet.com/a/img/resize/6bd4587def86e9b1261141196ef1cac4f6209007/hub/2024/04/16/660f9254-c869-4a08-9ba6-93c16106b001/ai-atlas-tag.png?auto=webp&width=768" alt="AI Atlas"><source media="(max-width: 1023px)" srcset="https://www.cnet.com/a/img/resize/6bd4587def86e9b1261141196ef1cac4f6209007/hub/2024/04/16/660f9254-c869-4a08-9ba6-93c16106b001/ai-atlas-tag.png?auto=webp&width=768" alt="AI Atlas"><source media="(max-width: 1440px)" srcset="https://www.cnet.com/a/img/resize/6bd4587def86e9b1261141196ef1cac4f6209007/hub/2024/04/16/660f9254-c869-4a08-9ba6-93c16106b001/ai-atlas-tag.png?auto=webp&width=768" alt="AI Atlas"> <img src alt="AI Atlas" height="268.29694323144105" width="768" loading="lazy"></picture></div> <!----> <!----></a> <!----></figure><p>"I think that makes sense," Altman said, "to really want the privacy clarity before you use it a lot, the legal clarity."</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p>More and more AI users are <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/can-ai-be-your-therapist-3-things-that-worry-professionals-and-3-tips-for-staying-safe/" target="_self">treating chatbots like their therapists</a>, doctors or lawyers, and that's created a serious privacy problem for them. There are no confidentiality rules and the actual mechanics of what happens to those conversations are startlingly unclear. Of course, there are other problems with using AI as a therapist or confidant, like how bots can give terrible advice or how they can <a href="https://www.massgeneralbrigham.org/en/about/newsroom/press-releases/llms-stigmatizing-language-alcohol-substance-use-disorder" target="_self">reinforce stereotypes or stigma</a>. (My colleague Nelson Aguilar has compiled a list of the <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/11-things-you-shouldnt-be-using-chatgpt-for/" target="_self">11 things you should never do with ChatGPT</a> and why.)</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p>Altman's clearly aware of the issues here, and seems at least a bit troubled by it. "People use it, young people especially, use it as a therapist, a life coach, I'm having these relationship problems, what should I do?" he said. "Right now, if you talk to a therapist or a lawyer or a doctor about those problems, there's legal privilege for it."</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p>The question came up during a part of the conversation about whether there should be <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/congress-isnt-stepping-up-to-regulate-ai-where-does-that-leave-us-now/" target="_self">more rules or regulations around AI</a>. Rules that stifle AI companies and the tech's development are unlikely to gain favor in Washington these days, as President Donald Trump's <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/trumps-ai-action-plan-is-here-5-key-takeaways/" target="_self">AI Action Plan</a> released this week expressed a desire to regulate this technology less, not more. But rules to protect them might find favor. </p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/features/ai-essentials-29-ways-to-make-gen-ai-work-for-you-according-to-our-experts/" target="_self">AI Essentials: 29 Ways You Can Make Gen AI Work for You, According to Our Experts</a></p><p>Altman seemed most worried about a lack of legal protections for companies like his to keep them from being forced to turn over private conversations in lawsuits. OpenAI has <a href="https://openai.com/index/response-to-nyt-data-demands/" target="_self">objected</a> to requests to retain user conversations during a lawsuit with the New York Times over <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/were-all-copyright-owners-why-you-need-to-care-about-ai-and-copyright/" target="_self">copyright infringement and intellectual property</a> issues. (Disclosure: Ziff Davis, CNET's parent company, in April filed a lawsuit against OpenAI, alleging it infringed Ziff Davis copyrights in training and operating its AI systems.)</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p>"If you go talk to ChatGPT about the most sensitive stuff and then there's a lawsuit or whatever, we could be required to produce that," Altman said. "I think that's very screwed up. I think we should have the same concept of privacy for your conversations with AI that you do with your therapist or whatever."</p><h2>Be careful what you tell AI about yourself</h2><p>For you, the issue isn't so much that OpenAI might have to turn your conversations over in a lawsuit. It's a question of whom you trust with your secrets.</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p>William Agnew, a researcher at Carnegie Mellon University who was part of a team that <a href="https://cse.umn.edu/college/news/new-research-shows-ai-chatbots-should-not-replace-your-therapist" target="_self">evaluated chatbots</a> on their performance dealing with therapy-like questions, told me recently that privacy is a paramount issue when confiding in AI tools. The uncertainty around how models work -- and how your conversations are kept from appearing in other people's chats -- is reason enough to be hesitant.</p><div data-ad-callout="Advertisement"><!----></div><p>"Even if these companies are trying to be careful with your data, these models are well known to regurgitate information," Agnew said.</p><p>If ChatGPT or another tool regurgitates information from your therapy session or from medical questions you asked, that could appear if your insurance company or someone else with an interest in your personal life asks the same tool about you. </p><p>"People should really think about privacy more and just know that almost everything they tell these chatbots is not private," Agnew said. "It will be used in all sorts of ways."</p></article></div></div> <div><!----> <!----> <!----> <!----> <!----> <!----> <!----></div></div> <div class="c-pageArticle_rightRail lg:u-col-4 md:u-col-6 shortcode=\"image\" uuid=\"d61443ea-77fc-4b49-abde-beafe10319e7\" size=\"large\" float=\"none\" image-caption=\"<p>OpenAI CEO Sam Altman testifies before a US Senate committee in May 2025.<\u002Fp>\" image-credit=\"Demetrius Freeman\u002FThe Washington Post via Getty Images\" image-alt-text=\"Sam Altman, a white man with graying dark hair, sits in front of a microphone.\" image-filename=\"gettyimages-2218523666.jpg\" image-date-created=\"2025\u002F07\u002F25\" image-width=\"1024\" image-height=\"683\" image-do-not-crop=\"false\" image-do-not-resize=\"false\" image-watermark=\"false\" lightbox=\"false\" edition=\"us\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMaybe don't spill your deepest, darkest secrets with an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Fbest-ai-chatbots\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003EAI chatbot\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. You don't have to take my word for it. Take it from the guy behind the most popular generative AI model on the market.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESam Altman, the CEO of \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Fchatgpt-plus-review\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003EChatGPT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E maker OpenAI, raised the issue this week in an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=aYn8VKW6vXA\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003Einterview\u003C\u002Fa\u003E with host Theo Von on the This Past Weekend podcast. He suggested that your conversations with AI should have similar protections as those you have with your doctor or lawyer. At one point, Von said one reason he was hesitant to use some AI tools is because he \"didn't know who's going to have\" his personal information.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cshortcode shortcode=\"image\" uuid=\"660f9254-c869-4a08-9ba6-93c16106b001\" size=\"small\" float=\"right\" image-caption=\"<p><\u002Fp>\" image-alt-text=\"AI Atlas\" image-target-url=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Fai-atlas\u002F\" image-filename=\"ai-atlas-tag.png\" image-date-created=\"2024\u002F04\u002F16\" image-width=\"1603\" image-height=\"560\" image-do-not-crop=\"false\" image-do-not-resize=\"false\" image-watermark=\"false\" lightbox=\"false\" edition=\"us\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\"I think that makes sense,\" Altman said, \"to really want the privacy clarity before you use it a lot, the legal clarity.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMore and more AI users are \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Fcan-ai-be-your-therapist-3-things-that-worry-professionals-and-3-tips-for-staying-safe\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003Etreating chatbots like their therapists\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, doctors or lawyers, and that's created a serious privacy problem for them. There are no confidentiality rules and the actual mechanics of what happens to those conversations are startlingly unclear. Of course, there are other problems with using AI as a therapist or confidant, like how bots can give terrible advice or how they can \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.massgeneralbrigham.org\u002Fen\u002Fabout\u002Fnewsroom\u002Fpress-releases\u002Fllms-stigmatizing-language-alcohol-substance-use-disorder\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003Ereinforce stereotypes or stigma\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. (My colleague Nelson Aguilar has compiled a list of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002F11-things-you-shouldnt-be-using-chatgpt-for\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003E11 things you should never do with ChatGPT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and why.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAltman's clearly aware of the issues here, and seems at least a bit troubled by it. \"People use it, young people especially, use it as a therapist, a life coach, I'm having these relationship problems, what should I do?\" he said. \"Right now, if you talk to a therapist or a lawyer or a doctor about those problems, there's legal privilege for it.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe question came up during a part of the conversation about whether there should be \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Fcongress-isnt-stepping-up-to-regulate-ai-where-does-that-leave-us-now\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003Emore rules or regulations around AI\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Rules that stifle AI companies and the tech's development are unlikely to gain favor in Washington these days, as President Donald Trump's \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Ftrumps-ai-action-plan-is-here-5-key-takeaways\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003EAI Action Plan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E released this week expressed a desire to regulate this technology less, not more. But rules to protect them might find favor. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead more:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Ffeatures\u002Fai-essentials-29-ways-to-make-gen-ai-work-for-you-according-to-our-experts\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003EAI Essentials: 29 Ways You Can Make Gen AI Work for You, According to Our Experts\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAltman seemed most worried about a lack of legal protections for companies like his to keep them from being forced to turn over private conversations in lawsuits. OpenAI has \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fopenai.com\u002Findex\u002Fresponse-to-nyt-data-demands\u002F\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003Eobjected\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to requests to retain user conversations during a lawsuit with the New York Times over \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fservices-and-software\u002Fwere-all-copyright-owners-why-you-need-to-care-about-ai-and-copyright\u002F\" rel=\"follow\"\u003Ecopyright infringement and intellectual property\u003C\u002Fa\u003E issues. (Disclosure: Ziff Davis, CNET's parent company, in April filed a lawsuit against OpenAI, alleging it infringed Ziff Davis copyrights in training and operating its AI systems.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\"If you go talk to ChatGPT about the most sensitive stuff and then there's a lawsuit or whatever, we could be required to produce that,\" Altman said. \"I think that's very screwed up. I think we should have the same concept of privacy for your conversations with AI that you do with your therapist or whatever.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EBe careful what you tell AI about yourself\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFor you, the issue isn't so much that OpenAI might have to turn your conversations over in a lawsuit. It's a question of whom you trust with your secrets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWilliam Agnew, a researcher at Carnegie Mellon University who was part of a team that \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcse.umn.edu\u002Fcollege\u002Fnews\u002Fnew-research-shows-ai-chatbots-should-not-replace-your-therapist\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003Eevaluated chatbots\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on their performance dealing with therapy-like questions, told me recently that privacy is a paramount issue when confiding in AI tools. The uncertainty around how models work -- and how your conversations are kept from appearing in other people's chats -- is reason enough to be hesitant.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\"Even if these companies are trying to be careful with your data, these models are well known to regurgitate information,\" Agnew said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf ChatGPT or another tool regurgitates information from your therapy session or from medical questions you asked, that could appear if your insurance company or someone else with an interest in your personal life asks the same tool about you. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\"People should really think about privacy more and just know that almost everything they tell these chatbots is not private,\" Agnew said. \"It will be used in all sorts of ways.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E",contentPlatform:{revisionId:h,entity:[],clusterId:[],ctopic:[p],ctax:[],csig:[]},dek:"The AI model is not your therapist and the company behind it can't necessarily keep it secret. Sam Altman thinks that's 'very screwed Before he was writing about sleep, he graduated as a Digital Communication Arts major from Oregon State University. After earning his certification from the Spencer Institute and dedicating hundreds of hours to sleep research, he has extensive knowledge on the topic and how to improve your quality of rest. Having more experience with lying on mattresses than most, Owen has reviewed over 150 beds and a variety of different sleep products including pillows, mattress toppers and sheets. Before he was writing about sleep, he graduated as a Digital Communication Arts major from Oregon State University. The current mattress Owen sleeps on is the Casper Nova Hybrid since it helps keep his spine in a comfortable, neutral position. When Owen isn't reviewing products, he loves to run, cycle and cook healthy food. readabilityObject.title: Even OpenAI's CEO Says Be Careful What You Share With ChatGPT
readabilityObject.content:
The AI model is not your therapist and the company behind it can't necessarily keep it secret. Sam Altman thinks that's 'very screwed up.'

Jon covers artificial intelligence. He previously led CNET's home energy and utilities category, with a focus on energy-saving advice, thermostats, and heating and cooling. Jon has more than a decade of experience writing and reporting, including as a statehouse reporter in Columbus, Ohio, a crime reporter in Birmingham, Alabama, and as a mortgage and housing market editor for Time's former personal finance brand, NextAdvisor. When he's not asking people questions, he can usually be found half asleep trying to read a long history book while surrounded by multiple cats. You can reach him at joreed@cnet.com

Expertise Artificial intelligence, home energy, heating and cooling, home technology.

Maybe don't spill your deepest, darkest secrets with an AI chatbot. You don't have to take my word for it. Take it from the guy behind the most popular generative AI model on the market.

Sam Altman, the CEO of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, raised the issue this week in an interview with host Theo Von on the This Past Weekend podcast. He suggested that your conversations with AI should have similar protections as those you have with your doctor or lawyer. At one point, Von said one reason he was hesitant to use some AI tools is because he "didn't know who's going to have" his personal information.

"I think that makes sense," Altman said, "to really want the privacy clarity before you use it a lot, the legal clarity."

More and more AI users are treating chatbots like their therapists, doctors or lawyers, and that's created a serious privacy problem for them. There are no confidentiality rules and the actual mechanics of what happens to those conversations are startlingly unclear. Of course, there are other problems with using AI as a therapist or confidant, like how bots can give terrible advice or how they can reinforce stereotypes or stigma. (My colleague Nelson Aguilar has compiled a list of the 11 things you should never do with ChatGPT and why.)

Altman's clearly aware of the issues here, and seems at least a bit troubled by it. "People use it, young people especially, use it as a therapist, a life coach, I'm having these relationship problems, what should I do?" he said. "Right now, if you talk to a therapist or a lawyer or a doctor about those problems, there's legal privilege for it."

The question came up during a part of the conversation about whether there should be more rules or regulations around AI. Rules that stifle AI companies and the tech's development are unlikely to gain favor in Washington these days, as President Donald Trump's AI Action Plan released this week expressed a desire to regulate this technology less, not more. But rules to protect them might find favor. 

Read more: AI Essentials: 29 Ways You Can Make Gen AI Work for You, According to Our Experts

Altman seemed most worried about a lack of legal protections for companies like his to keep them from being forced to turn over private conversations in lawsuits. OpenAI has objected to requests to retain user conversations during a lawsuit with the New York Times over copyright infringement and intellectual property issues. (Disclosure: Ziff Davis, CNET's parent company, in April filed a lawsuit against OpenAI, alleging it infringed Ziff Davis copyrights in training and operating its AI systems.)

"If you go talk to ChatGPT about the most sensitive stuff and then there's a lawsuit or whatever, we could be required to produce that," Altman said. "I think that's very screwed up. I think we should have the same concept of privacy for your conversations with AI that you do with your therapist or whatever."

Be careful what you tell AI about yourself

For you, the issue isn't so much that OpenAI might have to turn your conversations over in a lawsuit. It's a question of whom you trust with your secrets.

William Agnew, a researcher at Carnegie Mellon University who was part of a team that evaluated chatbots on their performance dealing with therapy-like questions, told me recently that privacy is a paramount issue when confiding in AI tools. The uncertainty around how models work -- and how your conversations are kept from appearing in other people's chats -- is reason enough to be hesitant.

"Even if these companies are trying to be careful with your data, these models are well known to regurgitate information," Agnew said.

If ChatGPT or another tool regurgitates information from your therapy session or from medical questions you asked, that could appear if your insurance company or someone else with an interest in your personal life asks the same tool about you. 

"People should really think about privacy more and just know that almost everything they tell these chatbots is not private," Agnew said. "It will be used in all sorts of ways."
